First, we need to understand who Leonardo da Vinci was. Leonardo da Vinci was an Italian artist, inventor, and polymath who lived during the Renaissance period in the 15th and 16th centuries. He was born in the city of Florence, Italy. 

Next, we need to understand the meaning of the question. The question is asking whether or not Leonardo da Vinci had contemporaries in his home city. "Contemporaries" means people who lived in the same time period as he did. "Home city" refers to Florence, the city where he was born.

Now, we can begin to answer the question. Leonardo da Vinci did not lack contemporary peers in Florence. In fact, during the Renaissance period, Florence was a hub of artistic and intellectual activity. There were many other artists, thinkers, and scientists who lived and worked in Florence at the same time as Leonardo da Vinci. Some of his contemporaries included Michelangelo, Raphael, and Botticelli.

Therefore, the correct answer is (B) no, Leonardo da Vinci did not lack contemporary peers in his home city.

The answer is no, he did not lack contemporary peers in Florence. During the Renaissance, Florence was a hub for artistic and scientific activity. There were other great artists and thinkers living and working in Florence at the same time as Leonardo da Vinci, such as Michelangelo and Raphael. These were his peers, and he was influenced by their work just as they were influenced by his.

Therefore, the answer to the question is (B) no, Leonardo da Vinci did not lack contemporary peers in his home city.
